definition:
A measurable function $f : \Omega \to \reals$ where
$(\Omega, \mathcal{A}, \mu)$ is a measure space is said to be
[**summable**]{} if the Lebesgue integral of the absolute value of $f$
exists and is finite, $$\int_{\Omega} |f| d\mu < +\infty$$ An
alternative way of expressing this condition is to assert that
$f \in L^1(\Omega)$.

Note that some authors distinguish between integrable and summable: an
integrable function is one for which the above integral exists; a
summable function is one for which the integral exists and is finite.
